title: How soon can citibank garnish wages/bank accounts in California after a judgement? Can they enter my home to take things?
question: I've just been served. Credit card is suing me for $32,000 I owe. They mailed me an offer a few months ago to settle for around $7,000, but we didn't have it then. We can probably have $6,000 to offer ($2,000 now, $2,000 each of the next two months), but we have other debts to settle. Our $70,000 HELOC is past due since December, we have a few medical bills past due (around $2,000 total) and another small credit card past due. Our home is foreclosing (will probably be sold in July/August) and we're emigrating to another country in a few months although we still intend to settle unresolved debts from there.
answers:
Your options are discussed in detail on the first video on my web site. The timing issue of what you can do and how much time you have after being served with a debt collection lawsuits is discussed in detail at my blog posting, linked below.

Robert Stempler
www.StopCollectionLawsuits.com

It takes time after service of a summons and complaint to get a judgment and then have the court issue and writ and then and only then can a judgment creditor levy wages and/or bank accounts. I would strongly advise calling the creditor and making a payment plan deal now before the situation gets any worse.

Attorney Frank is right, as usual. If you don't answer the complain, you will have no leverage with the creditor. As soon as a judgment is signed by the court, the creditor will have the right to ruin your life by seizing assets, such as your checking account. The creditor can also file liens against any real or personal property you own and can also garnish your wages.

Although you may think that emigrating will allow you to walk away unscathed, you may find it better to resolve this issue now rather than hiding from it. I would urge you to consider whether bankruptcy might not provide you with the kind of help you need.

Hope this perspective helps!

If you have just been served with the summons and complaint in the Citibank collection case, you have 30 days to answer. I strongly suggest that you either settle the case before you have to answer, or else file a general denial (rather than let a default judgment be entered against you).

If you ignore the summons and fail to answer, Citibank can obtain a default judgment against you anytime after the 30 days expires. Citibank can enforce the judgment by various methods such as garnishing wages and levying on bank accounts. However, Citibank cannot just go inside your home to take things.
